To be clear- "fiberglass insulation" would be the very worst thing to use. What he used is commonly known as "Kaowool" or ceramic fiber wool and left uncoated without a "rigidizer", is very harmful to your lungs. It is a "friable" material meaning when disturbed and made airborne such as when used in forced air gas forges without a coating of high temperature cement or similar refractory. While it is the best material to use, without a coating it will tear apart your lungs.

Fun Fact: Another resaon for the mentioned confusion between Tungsten and Gold is, that often the Xray-Tubes used in such analysis devices have a tungsten filament, that serves as an electron source. For those of you wondering if the Rolex is real or not, if you look closely at the 4:00 time stamp on the video, you will spot a Rolex logo on a gold piece that would typically be the clasp of the watch band. You can see that the clasp piece has some gold coming off of it with silver exposed underneath. Although he didn’t specify which year this watch came from, Rolex watches from that same time period (likely 80’s or 90’s) did not use gold plating. Also, if you look closely at the gold links and their sides which also belong to the Rolex bracelet, they too appear to have an exposed silver colored under metal where there might be gold plating scratched off but it would have been hard to tell without seeing them in person. He also made the statement around the 4:00 time stamp that the pieces all felt to be less than 14k gold and if that was the case, Rolex had never used anything other than pure 14 karat or 18 karat gold in their precious metal watches. Rolex does not use 24 karat gold since it is too soft. My suspicions of gold plating are also confirmed around the 20:27 time stamp on the video when he processes the disassembled “Rolex” bracelet. As he shows the processes the bracelet pieces, he states that the gold all seemed to be plated or seemed to be made of low Karat gold. You can also see the plating dissolving off of the bracelet pieces during the processing segment. There are also several things that also stick out to me as being off on the watch itself such as the magnification of the cyclops lens and the font that’s used for the date. The majority of all Rolex watches have a 2.5x magnification and a very specific date font and if you do a side by side comparison to other photos of other Datejust watches from this era, it looks off. The printing on the dial or “face” of the watch are also not super crisp and the gold plating on the crown and bezel of the watch are wearing away exposing the metal underneath. If this watch is truly from the time period its appears to be from, its impressive to see an automatic movement rather than a quartz movement that typically comes in a Rolex clone from this time period. I am about 99.9% sure its a counterfeit but the best way to 100% confirm its authenticity or lack thereof would be to take it to a Rolex jeweler or a trained watchmaker who would be able to confirm after removing the case back and observing the movement. It is also possible that even if it is a clone that it used a high amount of real gold for plating since there are several tiers of counterfeit Rolex watches with some ranging into the a few thousand dollars at their most expensive. My best guess would be that the majority of the gold that remained after he processed the watch bracelet remnants came from the added pieces of jewelry scrap and gold chain. I would also have to guess that a good part of the silver that he harvested from the nitric acid around the 27:50 time stamp was the metal that was beneath the plating on the bracelet links. With that being said, this is a really cool video and I found it very interesting!

My dad and uncle run a jewelry making business mainly working with 18K and 21K gold and they do this on a yearly basis after cleaning the workshop and processing the filth they collect in there. You’d be surprised how much gold you can get just from dust and the trash on the floor from a goldsmith’s workshop, well maybe not surprised since obviously it’s a gold workshop, but still the amount is huge. What’s great about their work though is that they started their business without anyone teaching them how to do it. My dad literally watched some jewelers work while waiting on them and decided that’s what he will do for a living. Only thing he had was his own wits and a bachelors degree in physics and a bit of knowledge/interest in chemistry and art to back him up when he started his business with my uncle. And now? I could honestly say he’s one of the best goldsmiths in our city.

Hello, next time you melt any precious metals, try using 75% Borax mixed with 25% Boric Acid. Both must be in granular form; powdered form is not suitable for torch melting. The mixture will attract moisture which can be stored in an airtight container in a refrigerator. You can use a ceramic or Quartz stirring rod during the melting process, graphite will contaminate the melting process. I use Hydrogen to melt my metals as its a much cleaner and hotter than map gas.
Gold doesn't have any iron or other ferris metals , you can use a magnet to test the metals if unsure.
24K is not 100% gold is 99.9% of gold :)

About “The Philosophers Stone!” The original versions I have found in numerous books suggest that the three elements that were used for the transmutation of lead into Gold were Mercury, Sulfur and Salt. However through many many books I’ve seen variations where some said you needed a tiny amount of actual gold to seed the process. Others claimed that it was Fools gold used in the process. Also that this process of achieving what they called “The Philosophers Stone” takes some time. Maybe even years of dilution, hydrating and Dehydrating and pulverizing the elements to weaken the atomic structure. The dilution process again was also mixed as I saw Phosphoric Acid and Citric acid and a few other acids. Never saw Nitric Acid however. Finally at some point you reach a certain point and the elements were supposed to be hermetically sealed in rock Crystal and then heated to a high temperature and that process is repeated for some time. Then in the final stage you reach a point where the elements become black but have a rainbow appearance and thus is called “Ravens Wing.” At some point you see a reaction that looks like stars and then it’s supposed to be taken to a dark place and unsealed and the substance is supposed to be kept in the dark sealed. A small piece was supposed to be taken and wrapped in beeswax and then dropped into molten lead. The reaction is supposed to change the  lead into gold. The secret they don’t say in all the versions of this formula I read was that if you succeeded in changing the lead into gold. You remove the gold from the crucible and then add water to the crucible and drink it. It’s supposed to make you young again. Some say immortal? Other versions say the water has to be drunk from the rock Crystal the “Ravens Wing” which successfully made gold. Is any of it true? IDK but I read a lot about it over the years. This is one of the stories which were attributed to the story of Compte De Saint Germain. Some say he discovered the secret and his death was never documented. Some claim he’s still alive. Again IDK? However there were also numerous cases of people poisoned by formulas that they thought would extend their lives. But I gathered none of those successfully transmuted lead into gold.

I had an 80 year old friend that died in 2016 who was into gold. He showed me how to do it over a few months, I bought old costume jewelry on eBay by the pound and we got the gold out of it using sulphuric acid (industrial drain cleaner from Home Depot) and a six volt battery charger, I think.
The charge combined with the acid caused the gold and copper and whatever else to come loose and become suspended in solution. I remember him talking about aqua regia but I don't think we used it during this process. He would also use some kind of citric acid to treat ore and ended up with fantastic fertilizer as a waste product. He even sold it to a local plant nursery.
I'm certain he would've found your video interesting and probably would've had some recommendations on improvements to your technique.

I’ve always been fascinated with HCl simply because that’s the main component in our stomach acid yet we, ya know, don’t die because of epithelial cells in our stomach that produce/secrete a bicarbonate-rich solution that forms a protective mucous shield on the surface in your stomach since the cells line your stomach. Bicarbonate is alkaline and neutralizes the acid secreted by the parietal cells; this produces water in the process. The continuous supply of bicarbonate is the primary way for your stomach to protect itself from the acidic environment and keeps the stomach from digesting itself. This is what your esophagus burns/hurts when you have acid reflux/throw up, since it doesn’t have that same protective coating. (P.S. stomach acid isn’t purely HCl, in fact it makes up very little of the overall mixture. Other components include potassium chloride (KCl) and sodium chloride (NaCl).)

Your procedure for recovering gold from copper alloys is out of date and your reaction proposal at 15:14 is incorrect.
HNO3 does not dissolve gold. It is the chlorine formed by the reaction of HNO3 and HCl that oxidizes gold to AuCl3 which, in the presence of HCl, forms soluble HAuCl4. You should watch one of my first rudimentary videos to understand the matter (Easiest way to dissolve gold https://youtu.be/aU5jjaYJ6Vw) or read my KAuCl4 preparation method in my book (see gdr6vn.html).

Your body contains trace amounts of other elements, such as silicon, manganese, fluorine, copper, zinc, arsenic, and aluminum. The going rate for a body's worth of these elements: just $1.

There are ways to bump up the price a bit. If you're looking to make a buck with your body, your best bet would be to sell individual organs, but since that's illegal, an alternative might be to tan your hide for use as leather. Your skin would be worth about $3.50 if it were sold at the price of a cowhide, which runs around $0.25 per square foot. If you take a dollar's worth of elements plus the value of your skin, you might be able to get $4.50, which you can round up to $5, so you can feel a bit better about your chemical value.

If you could harvest every organ and chemical in your body, you could make a $45 million . But in reality, Medical Transcription estimates, the average price of a human dead body is more likely to fetch around  $550,000 (with a few key body parts driving up the price).

As someone who has worked with gold a lot I always find it funny when people assume "malleable" means it's something like playdough and you can bend / shape it with just your hands. What malleable actually refers to is the ability of a metal to be flattened without breaking or deforming. Gold is really good at this, I think something like a single gram can be flattened into a cubic meter of foil.

Not that this is relevant so long after the video, but for most countries, gold has to legally follow certain standards, while this isn't true all around, most gold in the US, Mexico, Canada, Europe, etc. share mostly the same standards. Karat marked yellow gold has to be only gold, silver, and copper. White gold has more silver, less copper, and, in the US, it may include nickel. But in Canada and the EU, White gold cannot have nickel due to nickel allergies being quite common, in which case, white gold is gold, silver, copper, and palladium. Rose gold is more copper than silver. Uncommon elements like iron and zinc, or even aluminium to make green gold and other odd colours are extremely rare as they make working with gold extremely hazardous from a jeweler's perspective, and their working properties aren't really worth the hassle.

Source: I am a jeweler

Being a PhD in chemistry, I can say that the explication about the nitric acid attacking a very small amount of gold which is turned to HAuCl4 by HCl is completely FALSE. Too many chemistry teachers and random level amateur chemists (as we can see most of them on youtube) repeat this whitout understanding that it's not a "complex based" reaction, but a redox reaction.

Neither NO3- anion nor H+ cation can oxydize Au, because this metal needs more than +1,5V/SHE to be oxydized (highest redox potential of ALL metals). In Aqua Regia, HNO3 and HCl reacts to form atomic chlorine radical Cl* and nitrosyl chloride (NOCl) and this molecule decomposes also readily to NO* and Cl* radicals. It's this reaction :

3HCl+HNO3 -> 2Cl*+NOCl+2H2O -> 3Cl*+NO*+2H2O

Then the formed chlorine radicals attack and oxydize Au metal by being reduced to Cl- in the process :

3Cl*+Au -> AuCl3

This AuCl3 can't be formed by the direct attack of HCl on Au because HCl contain Cl- anion, not Cl* radical, Cl- anion doesn't have at all the oxydation properties of Cl* radical. Then AuCl3 fixes a free HCl to form HAuCl4 which is itself a strong acid and completely dissociates to H+ and AuCl4-.

This reaction is possible because the chlorine radical Cl* oxydizes Au easily, being a very powerful oxydizer with much higher oxydation potential (around +2,41V/SHE) than Au(+1,5V/SHE). In comparaison, HNO3 has "only" an oxydation potential around +0,8V/SHE on metals and it's +0V/SHE for H+ cation [it's the reason for why HCl or dilute H2SO4, both sources of H+, can oxydize some metals like Al, Zn, Mg, Co, Ni and Fe which have all oxydation potential less than that of H+ (0V/SHE), but the same acids can't oxydize other metals like Cu, Ag, Hg, Au, Pt, Ir, Pd which have all higher oxydation potential than that of H+].

And this Au oxydation is also possible with KClO3+HCl (potassium chlorate and hydrochloric acid) or NaClO+HCl (sodium hypochlorite and hydrochloric acid) mixture, because the same radical Cl* is produced again (ClO or ClO3 removes the only electron of Cl- to turn it to Cl* radical, like NO3- does the same with Cl-). The same thing happens with NaNO3+HCl or HNO3+NaCl, no need for absolutely 2 acids together. The oxydation of Au by HNO3+HCl is a simple redox reaction, nothing more. And another powerful oxydizer acid, called selenic acid H2SeO4 can also oxydize and dissolve gold.

The only "complex based" attacks on gold are made by Lugol's solution (complexation by I3-), cyanide solutions, thiourea solutions and some other complexing compounds. Sorry for my english.

After watching this and seeing what process is used to purify gold and silver (I also watched the waste video) it makes sense now as to why it’s difficult to find gold and silver at spot price. How I got here. I was annoyed because I really wanted to buy gold and silver at spot price but couldn’t find it without spending a thousand or so dollars on junk. (I don’t mind junk metal because it has more utility over cost but still..) So I thought to myself “how hard would it be to smelt it myself?”

So, yeah.
I don’t have the means to get started refining my own metal, but you helped me understand WHY they cost what they do.

Thank you.

Good choice to not trying to turn the Rolex into gold. It has a very low amount of it. The symbol on the winding stem is probably the majority of it. The movement is mostly brass (sometimes it has galvanic gold plating, some parts are steel), if it's automatically wound the bearing is steel, the rotor is sometimes gold, but not in Rolex watches, the bearings for the stems are ruby, the face is mostly brass, the case is steel and the glass is aluminium-oxide.
No watch is made out of gold. If you want pure gold out of a gold watch the wristband and case are the only parts which you should use.

I’m just going to say that zinc “vapor” fumes are not toxic. You might want to look into it. Sure it’s not good to breath as you can get metal fume fever but it’s not toxic and in high concentrations will make you feel like you have the flue. You just drink some milk and get some good rest and you will be right as rain. But this is in high concentrations from operations like welding on zinc coated steel. I would be way more worried about breathing in the fibers from your refractory wool. It is much more deadly and normally not uses unless it’s coated with a clay type coating to stabilize the fibers.

A further note on the Tungsten in the Gold: Tungsten is commonly used as a source material for x-ray apparatus, the spectra from the source itself is usually a mixture of Bremsstrahlung and fluorescent Tungsten radiation. Because of the difficulty in removing this perfectly and the longer calibration times of x-ray fluorescent detectors, sometimes a little bit of the source spectra ends up in the final reading. Its almost certainly not from the gold itself. As always a very enjoyable video.

Its certainly a good thing he processed that waste since its both valuable and moderately hazardous to the environment. Scrap metals on its own is typically useless, but for someone with a small forge and proper chemical set up you can recover ALOT of pure metals and its significantly more environmentally friendly to do that.

You'd be surprise how much you can make simply pulling metal parts from old household appliances (a typical window AC unit has a massive aluminum block and a fair amount copper pipe) and then selling to a scrapper.

Obviously you don't show every detail, but it looks like with the first test you used concentrated nitric acid and with the second chain you diluted the nitric acid.  Even pure copper won't dissolve in concentrated nitric acid because it forms a copper nitrate passivization layer.  You need water mixed with the acid to continually dissolve that layer and expose the metal to the acid.

Jeweller here: Great video!! Just a tip, although you didn't need it - when we melt our filings and we don't want the torch to blow the powder around, you can dissolve some boric acid in methylated spirits and use just enough to 'stick it' together. We sometimes go as far as taking the soaked mix and wrapping it into a little parcel using a tissue and burn the whole lot. Just don't use too much boric acid as when it melts into a glass, your gold can get stuck in it in small granular form. BUT you can then dissolve that in sodium bisulphate and water (we call it pickle)

Red - I know I'm late, but you could have made a much more efficient furnace using a microwave oven. Just take out the transformer, replace the secondary winding with one turn of 2 gauge wire and attach the output directly to the carbon crucible. Would have taken at most 45 seconds to melt all of that and you wouldn't have had to spend the time building the furnace or waste your MAPP torches. The rate of oxidation of the carbon crucible would also have been greatly reduced.

Quick note: I work with pure (99.999% and 99.9999% pure) gold at work and it is the most pain in the ass metal. It is extraordinarily fragile, doesn't hold its shape at all, and is just overall a PITA. Then again, I do work with relatively thin wires, but even the thick ones suck. The amount of work hardening is insane. You simply can't make anything out of "pure" (5 9s or 6 9s) gold. Unless it's a paperweight. Even then it would dent when dropped.

NileRed, I think the reason your gold is so "durable" is because it hasn't been annealed. Gold work hardens very rapidly. just like copper. Pure copper is extremely ductile and flexible, but with just a minute or so of flexing, you can harden it so much that it snaps. You cooled the gold very rapidly, which may well have caused it to harden more than expected. If you heat it again, and then slowly cool it down, it should be much more malleable.

NileRed: lets make gold

You could also reduce gold from solution by using FeCl2 (it's easily prepared by solving nails in the HCl) or hydrazine.
You can also test if all gold has been reduced by using SnCl2 solution. Just put one drop of your HFeCl4 solution on the piece of filter paper and put a drop of SnCl2 solution nearby. When those two solutions meet, if there appears a dark brown or black spot of reduced gold, that means that not all Au has been reduced yet. If there is no dark spot, it means there is no dissolved Au in the solution left. This reaction could be also used to test if your scrap contains gold - just dissolve a little piece of scrap in the mix of HCl and HNO3, and test the solution with SnCl2.

This was probably the best video on the topic I've seen. It's a shame Kitco's XRF is off, that wouldn't fly with me. The reading should be 995 or 996 with the remainder in silver. That's why 995+ is both the LBMA and Comex standard. The Miller Process is required above that, or electrolytic process. Undoubtedly, you also have gold left in solution. By the calculations you gave and the .5% that Kitco is out, your process is only about 96% efficient unless you recover what is left in solution. Likely less than 96% efficient as you took the dust weight, not the post melt weight. Something that you assumed was plated was also clearly not, I would guess the small chain was 10k. The plated stuff really isn't worth the process unless you have a kilo or two. Of course if I'm right, that leaves even more left in solution. Hopefully you didn't dispose of it as there's probably at least 200 good reasons to run an electric current through the chloroauric acid. At the end of the day, doing all this yourself isn't worth it. A good scrap dealer can do the same job, instantly for the same cost.

I don't know if this has been mentioned in the comments thus far, but I thought the origin of gold as an element might be of interest to some.  It's far more eloquently stated in the original PBS "Cosmos" series, in which Carl Sagan explains that the only place we're aware of in which the temperatures and pressures are great enough to squeeze atoms together to create gold is in supernova explosions.  The material of our sun and solar system are probably second or third generation, later-generation solar systems being made out of both our galaxy's native hydrogen and whatever stellar material might be in the neighborhood at the moment, in our case at least partially the remnants of a supernova explosion long ago.  Awesome channel and fascinating video!  Cheers.  :)

I have a problem with a lot of the Cash4Gold places. They're often marketed as sell your grandma's jewelry for real money.
This bothers me as very often pieces are over 60 years old and it's fairly common to melt down jewelry that is over 100 years old.
A lot of work and craftmanship went into the pieces and a lot of items from special brands or fancy sculptors are lost forever and can't be recreated. Most of the vintage jewelry is not appraised for its value other than just the value of straight gold. I've seen several pieces from the 1800s destroyed including artifacts from special time periods and even pieces designed for royalty,though of course that is more rare, but it used to very common to exchange items for royalty in the political setting. The worst was one I saw on a documentary that was estimated to be from the 1700-1800 Korean royalty. It was melted, the stone removed, and everything sold for scrap.
It's for this reason that I have a lot of respect for Mr. NileRed for not destroying the functioning watch.

A lot of people saying the rolex is fake but not giving any evidence. I pretty confident that it's fake for 2 main reasons.

First, the cyclops is barely magnifying the date. On a real rolex, the date is magnified to almost fill up the lens, this is far too small.

Second, the crown is sticking out way past the case. It's possible Nile wound it and forgot to screw it back down, but I don't think a datejust would have a screwdown crown in the first place.

Also the seconds hand looks like it could be 6 bps instead of 8 bps but I can't really tell.

I don't know enough of about the individual model to say anything else about its authenticity.

We recently had an incident at our uni where a geologist made 7 liters of aqua regia. Since aqua regia decomposes under formation of nitrosyl chloride and chlorine (an exothermic reaction), it started to boil vigorously and was constantly releasing toxic gas (quite a problem since the lab only has one semi-functional fume hood).
The fire brigade came in and they tried neutralizing it with Sodium bicarbonate - turns out that just makes it even harder to control since it heats up and starts foaming like crazy. By that point the whole thing had been going on for a few hours, and they ended up calling our chemistry department to fix the issue. In the end, one of our Profs and a Postdoc had to personally come in and clean up the mess for them.
So how do you actually clean up a bucket of bubbling aqua regia? Put on your gas mask and, under constant stirring (they were using a broomstick to stir), add some hundred pounds of ice to dilute and cool the solution, then slowly add Sodium or Potassium hydroxide to neutralize it.

Little sidenote about Tungsten: It can also be "found" in trace amounts when you are analyzing via mass spectroscopy: The heating element of the ion source is made of a Tungsten alloy (as it has to withstand rather high temperatures), together with the electric spark gap needed to generate a plasma in the first place... This mostly happens with old spectrometers, so just be aware of that when you suddenly "find" new elements in your sample.

The method these spectrometers work often times is with X-Rays in this method is Gold is VERY close to Tungsten and ind some lower grade tiers of spectrometers there wont be gold showing up at all and just Tungsten (even if you scanned a piece of metal that has gold in it). So knowing their spectrometers, they probably told you that the Gold is 100% because the 0.95 % Tungsten is still gold but misjudged by the spectrometer.

EDIT: As you can see on the silver chart, there is still spikes in some other materials that are not silver. For example the X-Ray picked up trace (almost infinitely small) amounts of Zirconium. These spectrometers work with abnormously high precision, counting every single atom.

"Aqua Regia"
Ah yes, one of the 4 chemicals needed to get past that fleshy mess to get to the part where you see the monster dude

New experiment!
Things you will need:
2 32 oz. Gatorade bottles
2 Mason jars
3-4 ft. of aquarium tubing
aquarium air pump (optional)
fine coffee filters
a funnel
75g 100% lye
130g 15-0-15 fertilizer (no weed killers)
2 96 ct. Pseudophedrine (crushed into fine powder)
Coleman lantern fuel
1.5g Ice
2 AA lithium batteries
Iodized Salt
Liquid Lightning (drain cleaner)
Pipe cutter
Needle nose pliers
Xacto knife/Scissors
The process:
Take your 2 gatorade bottles and clean them out using a coat hanger and paper towels, making sure there is no liquid in the bottles. Rinse with a little lantern fuel and repeat. The goal is to get the bottles clean of everything. Once clean, drill 2 holes the width of the aquarium tubing into the cap of one of the bottles and set aside. This will be your “smoke bottle”. Take the other bottle and combine the lye, fertilizer, pseudo, and lantern fuel. Add enough fuel till the mix is to the line aprox. where the top of the label would be. Recap and let this mix sit for 24 hours. Once this is complete, take your pipe cutter and open the 2 lithium batteries, exposing the litium strips inside(they look kinda like tin foil). Cut up these strips into small pieces and add them to your mixture. Then add your 1.5g of ice(just a little bit! 1.5g ice isn’t much). Immediately cap and begin to shake. The water from the ice and the litium will begin to react and you will see it “flaming up” inside the bottle. Don’t freak out and throw the bottle/run from the room etc., as this is natural. Constantly shake your bottle, and take note of the pressure building inside of it. When the bottle becomes hard from the pressure(kinda like a shooken up soda), you will need to burp your bottle. Stop shaking and quickly burp the bottle, making sure your hand is over the cap so it doesn’t fly off from the pressure. Once burped, close and begin shaking again. Repeat this until you notice that it isn’t building pressure anymore(usually around 1 1/2-2 hours). Your liquid should now be clear again like the lantern fuel before you started.
Filter this mixture into one of your mason jars, using 3-4 coffee filters and your funnel. Throw away the filtered gunk into your gatorade bottle that you just used. The liquid in your mason jar is good dope, but we need to smoke it now. Take your other gatorade bottle with the 2 holes drilled in the top. Put equal pieces of aquarium tubing into each hole, making sure they fit snug into the holes. Attach one end to your aquarium pump (or you can use good ol’ fashioned lung power, but I disadvise since this stuff is pretty toxic). Now combine your salt and Liquid Lightning(I didn’t give amounts, but you can fill your smoker bottle with 1/4 cup of salt and a couple of drops of the LL). You will notice the mix starting to give off smoke. Cap your bottle and let the smoke build. Once this has happened, either plug in your pump or begin to blow into one tube. The other tube should be sitting in your dope mix. Now here’s a kicker so you don’t have harsh dope…swirl your smoke in your dope for only a sec or two, just until you begin seeing the crystals fall into the bottom(kinda like a snow globe :-P) and then stop! Filter the mix into your other mason jar and throw away filter in first bottle. This introduced the smoke to your mix, and now you can smoke your mix to get the good stuff. Smoke your mix again, but this time continue smoking it until you stop seeing the snow fall. This “snow” is now pure crystal meth. Filter again, but keep this filter, as it contains your dope. Repeat smoking process again to get all the leftover meth out of your mix, and filter it with your “good” filter. Allow to dry and enjoy! Throw leftover mix into first gatorade bottle, along with used coffee filters. Dispose of discreetly(not in your trash!!!!).
P.S. When shaking your bottle, be very carefull not to get distracted and let the bottle just sit. Also, be mindfull of the pressure in the bottle and burp when needed. Failure to do either of these could result in your face getting melted off.

Doing it by inquarting the gold is actually the best way to do it with karat gold like that jewelry. The other way to do it is to raise the gold percentage to the point it won't passivate in the aqua regia due to the percentage of silver and or copper. This assumes you have enough gold to do that with. If you do, you can just go right to the aqua regia step and the silver should be left behind in solid form just like the gold is doing it the way you did it. It was interesting to see you use potassium metabisulfite since usually sodium metabisulfite is used. Using as little nitric acid as possible in the aqua regia mix also means you don't have to neutralize the excess with something like urea.

Real quick thing about the gold when you were trying to flatten it. Gold becomes work hardened as you apply forces(such as a hammer strike) to it. Heating it up to a red hot and letting it cool back down will soften the metal and make it somewhat more malleable. When you said the lighter-colored precipitate might indicate higher purity, was that conjecture? I'm not sure myself, but one possible contrary explanation could be that the hydrochloric acid dissolved the most "exposed" gold atoms available, yielding less-jagged particles on a microscopic level. I wouldn't have touched this offer with a 10 foot pole. There are all SORTS of laws that you could have broken without even knowing it.

Even the process of RECOVERING the gold from scraps of jewelry CAN be illegal (Or heavily regulated) in some areas if you aren't a jeweler, because it makes laundering stolen jewelry trivial.

Further, businesses that take scrap gold usually have to follow 'Pawn Shop' rules that require notifying the police when taking in items. And holding those items for a minimum amount of time (90 days is common) to allow for any reported thefts to be investigated. And since this channel is a 'business' those likely apply to you since you didn't own those scraps until recently.

EVEN Further. If that Rolex was REAL, and still in working condition (or even moderately repairable) it would almost CERTAINLY be worth more than the scrap gold.
(A working Rolex, even those with a quarts movement, are usually worth a minimum of $1500 if they work)
